messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Combinatorial Resultants in the Algebraic Rigidity Matroid

Paper Abstract: Abstract Motivated by a rigidity-theoretic perspective on the Localization Problem in 2D, we develop an algorithm for computing circuit polynomials in the algebraic rigidity matroid CMnsubscriptCMùëõ\operatorname{CM}_{n} associated to the Cayley-Menger ideal for nùëõn points in 2D. We introduce combinatorial resultants, a new operation on graphs that captures properties of the Sylvester resultant of two polynomials in the algebraic rigidity matroid. We show that every rigidity circuit has a construction tree from K4subscriptùêæ4K_{4} graphs based on this operation. Our algorithm performs an algebraic elimination guided by the construction tree, and uses classical resultants, factorization and ideal membership. To demonstrate its effectiveness, we implemented our algorithm in Mathematica: it took less than 15 seconds on an example where a Gr√∂bner Basis calculation took 5 days and 6 hrs.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "On the maximal number of real embeddings of minimally rigid graphs in R2, R3 and S2",
        "What Can Be Computed In Algebraic Geometry?",
        "A proof of Connelly‚Äôs conjecture on 3-connected circuits of the rigidity matroid",
        "Computing the dimension of a polynomial ideal",
        "Point configurations and Cayley-Menger varieties",
        "The number of embeddings of minimally rigid graphs",
        "Ein algorithmisches Kriterium f√ºr die L√∂sbarkeit eines algebraischen Gleichungssystems",
        "Computing the number of realizations of a Laman graph",
        "Ideals, Varieties, and Algorithms. An Introduction to Computational Algebraic Geometry and Commutative Algebra",
        "Primary Decomposition: Algorithms and Comparisons",
        "On some combinatorial properties of algebraic matroids",
        "The structure of polynomial ideals and Gr√∂bner bases",
        "Apolarity and canonical forms in homogeneous polynomials",
        "Commutative Algebra, with a View Toward Algebraic Geometry, volume 150 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Computer algebra methods for studying and computing molecular conformations",
        "Mixed Volume and Distance Geometry Techniques for Counting Euclidean Embeddings of Rigid Graphs",
        "Absolute irreducibility of polynomials via newton polytopes",
        "Newton Polytopes of the Classical Resultant and Discriminant",
        "Discriminants, Resultants, and Multidimensional Determinants",
        "Sulle variet√° rappresentate coll‚Äôannullare determinanti minori contenuti in un determinante simmetrico od emisimmetrico generico di forme",
        "Combinatorial rigidity, volume 2 of Graduate Studies in Mathematics",
        "Principles of algebraic geometry",
        "On symmetric and skew-symmetric determinantal varieties",
        "Die graphische Statik der starren Systeme",
        "Dividing a graph into triconnected components",
        "Representation of Matroids",
        "Basic Algebra II: Second Edition",
        "Classes of determinantal varieties associated with symmetric and skew-symmetric matrices",
        "Algebra, volume 211 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Pebble game algorithms and sparse graphs",
        "CayleyMenger - Circuit Polynomials in the Cayley Menger ideal, a GitHub repository",
        "Circuit polynomial for the K3,3-plus-one circuit",
        "Combinatorial Resultants in the Algebraic Rigidity Matroid",
        "The space complexity of elimination theory: upper bounds",
        "On the calculation of the equilibrium and stiffness of frames",
        "Dimension-dependent bounds for Gr√∂bner bases of polynomial ideals",
        "Complexity of membership problems of different types of polynomial ideals",
        "Matroid theory, volume 21 of Oxford Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Algebraic Matroids in Applications",
        "algebraic-matroids, a GitHub repository",
        "Algebraic matroids in action",
        "Characterizing graphs with convex and connected Cayley configuration spaces",
        "Connectivity in graphs",
        "Moderne Algebra, 2nd edition",
        "Algebra. Vol. 2",
        "On a nine-bar linkage, its possible configurations and conditions for flexibility",
        "Some matroids from discrete applied geometry"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Combinatorial Resultants in the Algebraic Rigidity Matroid, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
